A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
Does the concept of a/an Polynomial need to be defined for a definition of a/an Irreducible Polynomial to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand whether a polynomial is irreducible, one must first understand what a polynomial is. The definition of an irreducible polynomial explicitly references the concept of a polynomial, stating that it is a polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$. This implies that the polynomial is of the form $f=\nsum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, as defined in the concept of a Polynomial. Without understanding this structure, one cannot determine if a polynomial can be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials, because the very notion of factoring requires understanding the components (terms) of the polynomial. Therefore, the concept of a Polynomial is necessary to make sense of what an Irreducible Polynomial is.
